[Here's a breakdown](http://www.cincyjungle.com/2013/3/5/4065394/a-history-lesson-on-2013-nfl-free-agency-remember-plan-b-free-agency).  Teams used to basically hold the rights of players forever. Then in 1989, "Plan B" free agency was instituted that allowed teams to retain the rights to "only" 37 players.

Eight players sued to end this practice, and that's what ultimately led to our current system.  Fun fact, during this process, Pat Bowlen was so worried about losing John Elway that he lobbied for the inclusion of some sort of mechanism for teams to be able to protect a star player, and the franchise tag was born.

Some additional info about the involvement of Reggie White and Plan B free agency:

[In-depth legal breakdown of 1993 settlement](http://www.leagle.com/decision/19932294836FSupp1458_12126/WHITE%20v.%20NATIONAL%20FOOTBALL%20LEAGUE)

[NY Times article about 1992 jury trial over Plan B free agency](http://www.nytimes.com/1992/09/11/sports/football-nfl-s-free-agency-system-is-found-unfair-by-us-jury.html) 

White was one of the named plaintiffs in a class action case filed just two weeks after the 1992 case mentioned in the NYT link that challenged what was known as [Plan B Free Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_B_free_agency). The case was heard by Judge Doty of the 8th circuit who came to be viewed as player friendly, and he continued to hear CBA related cases, including the lawsuit over the lockout, which is why the NFL proactively [asked a NYC court to uphold the Brady suspension](http://mweb.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25252540/report-nfl-requests-nyc-court-to-uphold-tom-brady-appeal-ruling) (mobile link) so that they had less of a chance to wind up in Doty's Minnesota court again.

No, they did not break the rules.  The NFL, by their own admission, did not know what the ideal gas law was.

http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/08/05/transcript-proves-nfl-didnt-know-air-pressure-could-drop-naturally/

Dozens of university professors sent a document to the courts during the trial explaining that the deflation was expected in cold weather.  But that doesn't even matter.  This is something that is taught in middle school science classes across the country. You can do the experment at home by yourself.

http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2016/05/25/scientists-submit-brief-in-support-of-tom-brady/

If you take a ball inflated to the lower-limit of the allowed PSI (12.5), then bring it outside in ~40 degree temperatures for 90 minutes (similar to the AFC Championship game), then bring it back inside and measure it again, the PSI will be lower.

Add that to the fact that the NFL was using two gauges to measure pressure, one of which consistently returned readings 0.4 PSI lower than the other.

These two things together give you the PSI readings seen in the data recorded from halftime during the game, and published in the Wells Report.  (Worth noting, 3 of the 4 Colts balls were below the allowed minimum, as well, but they stopped measuring.  They also recorded PSI measurements for games in the 2015 season, but refuse to release them.)
